title: U.S. stocks open higher Thursday, buoyed by upbeat earnings from Nvidia and Macy's
text:
The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA edged down 16.81 points, or less than 0.1%, to 35,914.24.

The S&P 500 SPX rose 8.63 points, or 0.2%, to 4,697.30.

The Nasdaq Composite COMP was up 43.64 points, or 0.3%, at 15,965.21.

On Wednesday, the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite all lost ground in a subdued trading session. The S&P 500 remained just 0.3% away from its record close, with the Nasdaq Composite just 0.4% its all-time high finish.

What's driving markets?

A strong quarter from graphics chip maker Nvidia Corp.NVDA, which reported a 50% jump in revenue late Wednesday, helped to buoy sentiment. Shares jumped 11%.

Corporate earnings have beaten Wall Street estimates in the third quarter, as strong demand has helped to offset the pressure from supply-chain disruptions.

In U.S. economic data, new filings for jobless benefits slipped by 1,000 to 268,000 in the seven days ended Nov. 13, the government said. Economists polled by The Wall Street Journal had estimated initial jobless claims would total a seasonally adjusted 260,000.

See: Why the stock market could hit a peak Friday, before ‘minor' dip Thanksgiving week

The Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank's manufacturing index jumped in November to 39 from 23.8.

Chicago Fed President Charles Evans said late Wednesday that the disruptions have lasted longer than he anticipated, though he still expects the central bank to end its bond-buying program in the middle of 2022 as currently planned.

Markets will be highly tuned into any signals on who President Joe Biden will pick to chair the Fed. Biden on Tuesday said a decision would come “in about four days.” The decision is widely seen as coming down to a choice between renominating Chairman Jerome Powell or choosing Fed Gov. Lael Brainard.

Barron's: Who Will Be the Next Fed Chair? Why Brainard Is Gaining on Powell.

“Stock markets have been resilient all year; they have looked through upside surprises in inflation, downside surprises in growth, and a dramatic change in central bank pricing,” said strategists at Barclays led by Ajay Rajadhyaksha. The Barclays strategists see limited upside to U.S. equities but also don't expect a major selloff, as there's significant downside hedging.

Read: Here's what a 1970s inflation-fighting fiasco says about the battle against rising prices

Which companies are in focus?

Results also continued to roll in from major retailers. Shares of Macy's Inc.M jumped 10.6% after reporting third-quarter results that soared past expectations, while Kohl's Corp.KSS shares advanced 5% after beating forecasts.

Shares of Cisco Systems Inc.CSCO fell 8.5% after delivering disappointing guidance.

Deere & Co. DE shares rose 2.3% after it reached a new agreement with workers and a strike since Oct. 14 was called off.

What are other markets doing?

The yield on the 10-year Treasury note BX:TMUBMUSD10Y fell 0.3 basis point to 1.604%. Yields and debt prices move in opposite directions.

The ICE U.S. Dollar Index DXY, a measure of the currency against a basket of six major rivals, was little changed.

Oil futures bounced higher, with the U.S. benchmark CL00 up 0.6% at $78.01 a barrel, while gold futures GC00 fell 0.3%.

The Stoxx Europe 600 XX:SXXP fell 0.2%, while London's FTSE 100 UK:UKX wad down 0.3%.

The Shanghai Composite CN:SHCOMP fell 0.5%, while the Hang Seng Index HK:HSI declined 1.3% and Japan's Nikkei 225 JP:NIK was off 0.3%.
